awd_titl_txt: TWC: TTP Option: Small: Collaborative: Integrated Smart Grid Analytics for Anomaly Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The modernized electric grid, the Smart Grid, integrates two-way communication technologies across power generation, transmission and distribution, in order to deliver electricity efficiently, securely and cost-effectively. On the monitoring and control side, it employs real-time monitoring offered by a messaging-based advanced metering infrastructure (AMI), which ensures the grid?s stability and reliability, as well as the efficient implementation of demand response schemes to mitigate bursts demand. The efficient implementation of these features presents a number of challenges, but also opportunities for technology development in engineering, networking, and data analytics.

The intellectual contributions include the development of a framework that encompasses fast signal processing and machine learning algorithms, together with multi-sensor information to assess the health of the network. Specifically, the study will investigate algorithms for adaptive detection over streaming, high-dimensional and potentially missing value data. Furthermore, the project, via industry collaborators and power provisioners, will provide a comprehensive empirical evaluation with real-world data; this includes an open-source proof-of-concept prototype for quickly inferring nefarious activity in home-area networks, and a cloud-based testbed for examining realistic scenarios in a wide-area setting.

por.por_cntn:
The modern "Smart Grid" utilizes advanced two-way communication methods to enhance the safety, reliability, security and maintenance of its networks. On the other hand, such methods may widen the attack surface of such networks through possible malicious attacks through spoofed transmitted data; also referred to as "false data injection," which may perturb the stability of the grid.

This is where our project came in, as we introduced techniques in a "modern home" setting where we monitored various sensor measurements, including luminosity, temperature, and motion) and performed data fusion into machine learning and statistical methods to detect false data injections through inferring anomalies. This situational awareness approach allowed us to detect possible well-orchestrated attacks on residential smart meters.

In the Transition-to-Practice part of this project, we utilized affordable off-the-shelf components such as the Raspberry Pi and Arduino, along with Z-wave based wireless sensors. We partnered with a leading institution in the energy industry and tested our infrastructure at their "Smart Home." This partnership proved to be very successful and provided value to all parties involved.

The team also explored the Wide Area Network monitoring. Our goal was to detect abnormal spoofing and tampering through taking advantage of structural similarities in smart meters' reported electrical consumption. Clusters of meters with similar energy consumption were created to handle the "curse of dimensionality" problem. False data injection attacks were identified through statistical/temporal models based on state abnormalities. Data infused with stealth attacks was used to evaluate these approaches and results were promising.

This project had the overarching challenging goal of providing critical infrastructure defenders with machine learning techniques that may balance out their continuous uneven battle with attackers. We posted our software implementations on Github as open source for their perusal. Our project also provided our diverse students from EMU and UM with the opportunities to gain great experience in multiple areas, including information and network security, statistics, and hardware setup and configuration.

Modified by: Samir Tout
